transcripts.message:
I Darius Branch, of Castleton in the
County of Rutland, and State of Vermont,
testify and say, that I was living with
my Father in the south east part
of Bennington, in the fall of the year
1782, near the residence of Capt. 
Jonathan Scott and was present at
his house in the early part of Sep-
tember (as I think) and saw Samuel
Holmes and Salena Scott united
in marriage by Moses Robinson, Esq.
I cannot recollect the precise day of the
month, but distinctly remember that
there was a party of Tories discovered
going through a flat in the east-
erly part of Bennington, which 
caused the inhabitants to suspect that
all was not right; — the alarm was
immediately given to my Father and
others, and a Company of men raised
who went in pursuit and 
suring them about eight miles captur-
ed them on the Green Mountain,
I think twelve in number, with a
Capt. Blakslee and a negro man
whom the Tories had taken and
were carrying off or leading off
to Canada, I was too young to be
one of the pursuers, being now
in my seventy eighth year, and am con-
fident that Samuel Holmes was
one of the Party. — I was present at
the house of Gen. Samuel Safford and
saw the Tories when they were brought
in by our Troops, I was intimately acquain-

transcripts.message:
"State of Tennessee
Davidson County

On this 14th day of May appearing in open court before the Judge of the Circuit Court for said county William L. Brown who being duly sworn says that he is a citizen of said State and county, that he is well acquainted with John Dickey who was a private in Capt. John Tann's Company of Colo. [Colonel] James Cox's Regiment of the North Carolina Line – That this deponent has been intimately acquainted with said Dickey for thirty years past and upwards – that he is confident that said Dickey lived in the year 1778, but cannot say where or how long – that he served three months as aforementioned, that this deponent never heard him mention any other service in the Revolutionary War than what is above stated – That this deponent verily believes from his knowledge of said Dickey and of men who lived at that time that said Dickey served out the full term of three months, he having no knowledge or suspicion to the contrary.

Sworn to and subscribed in open court the day and year above written
William L. Brown"

transcripts.message:
The image contains the text of a Revolutionary War Pension application for John W. Hunnicutt, who served in the North Carolina militia during the war. Here is the transcription:

STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA }
JOHNSTON COUNTY }

On this 21st day of October, A.D. one thousand eight hundred and thirty two personally appeared before me, John W. Hunnicutt, a resident of said County and State, aged Sixty Nine years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed June 7th, 1832:

That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers, and served as herein stated:

He volunteered his services in the North Carolina Militia, in the year 1780 or 1781, as a private man, under Captain James Fletcher, who belonged to Colonel Grants Regiment. He marched from his home in Johnston County, to Cross Creek (now Fayetteville) where he was stationed several months - during which time he was engaged in building Fort Williams; afterwards he marched with the same Company and Officers to Wilmington, where they were stationed some time as a guard over prisoners. He does not recollect the time of his discharge from said service, but thinks it was about the year 1782 or 1783; he never received any written discharge, nor has he any record of his services.

He further declares that he has no property, except a house and lot valued at about Two Hundred Dollars - which is not enough to support him; and that during the Revolutionary War he was a farmer and resided in Johnston County, North Carolina, where he has lived ever since, engaged in agricultural pursuits.

He hereby relinquishes every claim to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of any agency in any State.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.

John W. Hunnicutt

We John S. McLelland and Jas. A. McLelland, Clerks of the Court of Pleas and Quarter Sessions for Johnston County, do hereby certify that John W. Hunnicutt, who is personally known to us, signed his name to us, after being duly sworn, and that we believe him to be Sixty Nine years of age.

In testimony whereof, we have hereunto subscribed our names and affixed the seal of said Court, at Smithfield, this 21st day of October A.D. 1832.

Jno S. McLelland, Clk
Jas. A. McLelland, D. Clk
